title: Have You Heard of Nikolai Astrup? | The New Yorker

quotes: I was riveted by one moment in time, “Gray Spring Evening” (before 1908), in which a massive, still snowy peak looms beyond a thawing lake.
He lamented in a letter to a friend in 1922, “I ruin practically every serious work that I have made recently. I am so uncertain.”
I have been to Norway and like it fine, as any gadabout New Yorker might.
My chief stirring of emotional identity is with North Dakota, where my immigrant people went and I was born.

locations.place: Lofoten Islands, in the Arctic Circle
quotes: But I recommend the sublime Lofoten Islands, in the Arctic Circle. There, one June night, I watched the sun start to set and then think better of it.
